522779038 This way it seems Russian state entities are threatening to use the 1989 Belgium Luxembourg BLEU USSR bilateral investment treaty BIT to sue Belgium over the European Union s EU plan to back a EUR 140 billion Ukraine support loan with immobilized Russian central bank assets held in Belgium No case has been filed yet but Belgian officials treat it as a credible risk and are currently vetoing the loan BITs are international agreements between two countries that set rules to protect and promote investments made by investors of one country in the territory of the other

BRUSSELS The European Commission is offering a legal fix to allay Belgium s fears of a nightmare scenario that could unfold if 140 billion in Russian assets frozen in Brussels are used as a loan to Ukraine The Commission wants the 27 EU member countries to agree to lend the immobilized billions to Kyiv at a European Council summit this month Belgium is resisting however over concerns it will be on the hook if the cash has to go back to Russia Five diplomats and EU officials said a legal framework was now being drawn up to prevent that from happening A full proposal on the loan is expected on Wednesday Belgium's ultimate fear is that if the 140 billion is lent to Ukraine a single pro Russian EU country such as Hungary or Slovakia could veto the renewal of the EU's sanctions regime against Moscow That would require Belgium to immediately return the missing billions to Russia The Commission's fix to keep Belgium happy is to prevent individual EU countries from being able to overturn sanctions Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orb n currently has the power to do exactly that as sanctions require unanimity and must be renewed every six months

107412992 AMPS DACS Atom2 Stack pretty much your entry level stack combos Atom2 is gonna run more transparent flat neutral but is built like a tank JDS Element 4 Big improvements on the shortcomings of the pretty lackluster Ele series You're paying for convenience build quality and the best customer service here They're building an ecosystem around their Core app here which gives you a 10 band PEQ with a preset database sharable profiles artificial soundstage sliders etc Bit overpriced but worth it as a simple plug and play if you're not going above 650s or equivalents Schiit Mimir ESS DAC with newer technology tuning digital pre amp tech you can bluetooth Has solved issues previous ESS DACs have with soundstaging Schiit Gungnir 2 Byggy Most people will tell you DACs are all the same that typically runs true Jason from Schiit recently forced a bunch of redactions on posts about CanJam Socal this year when a SBAF poster started sharing stuff said in confidence on how they're experimenting with DAC technology to try and produce different sound results If you've ever had either of these you'll know they have characteristics you usually wouldn't expect from a DAC more muscular and slam across the sound Is that worth the price point for something a lot will tell you is magic in a solved system For me after hearing them yeah but I wouldn't spend on them unless you can try them first the Byggy is probably as far as anyone should go on DAC spending beyond that its fugazi NITSCH Pietus Maximus CEE TEE of Massdrop fame's baby It's basically a pimped out Asgard using experimental Schiit tech Jason passed him This thing rules can be fitted with a Mesh or ESS dac to be a standalone Sounds like wet bloomy tube noise but in a SS amp Also drives planars extremely well Covers 16 ohm range too this is probably your 'afforadble' go to for low impedance stuff

107406079 If you haven't added a custom password for it then it's locked with your Windows login credentials You won't be able to access that drive from outside of that specific Windows installation So even a clean Windows install would fail to access it even if you have a user with the same name and password since unique user credentials are created each time a Windows user is created At this point I suppose the best option would be to just turn off Encryption If you want the disk accessible by all operating systems then yes I can't seem to access the root drive I setup while setting up Pop wants a password doesn't work with mine at setup Each Linux OS has a separate user called root which has it's own password If you didn't set it up yourself then the root password is random and never given out to you To give your user root access it needs to be in the sudoers file udoers if it is here you can confirm by just running sudo su and typing your own password then you should be able to use your own password whenever you're prompted to access something that requires the root user I have no idea if this is some PopOS quirk since I generally avoid distributions which haven't been worked on in over 2 years

107419657 Anyone know how to deal with fumes when soldering Ideally you don't Avoid them if you can I'm in a basement and the only window I have is on the other side of the room Not great The issue is that most of those cheap ones suck ass and are about as good as no filter at all I'd say if you're tight on money get a PC fan desk fan strap a HEPA filter to it and maybe some carbon based filter behind that There exist good ones that suck out air and work like a fume hood but we're talking hundreds of dollars for those The ultimate I'll get cancer but at least later method is you just have a fan that blows away from you so it doesn't directly blow into your eyes and nose try to get your soldering done quickly then vacate the room and open the window to air as much of it out as you can Ghetto as fuck and not ideal but it'll at least help You can also wear a filter mask I sometimes used to but I am dubious that actually does anything from a health perspective

107413685 I bought a similar style watch from Escapement Time The only thing is that I wish it had a metal back and not the glass back Haven't been able to find anything but I do know the back plate is 39mm 107419094 Water beads are essentially slightly altered silica gel balls They will have an upper limit in how much water they can suck up They still deteriorate because the beads can get damaged or burst That being said they'll last a couple months at most if you leave them in a vase like that They will deteriorate though sunlight and just exposure to water and air They're pretty fragile when they're pumped full of water Arguably the biggest hurdle for something like what you're doing is going to be stuff growing in the vase You're pretty much making a really dirty aquarium you will get algae growth even with a lid 107419920 Don't even use a filter You're trying to extract fumes you need unobstructed airflow to get the most fumes out The filter will slow extraction a little bit and there's no benefit other than slightly filtering the air before it goes outside Completely pointless and you now have a false sense of security There are airbrush stations for around 100 last time I was looking They are little fume extractors with fans and a filter that take paint fumes and dump em out a window take the filter out and it's pretty good Might be a good solution

107371066 I implemented clustered shading which makes adding 1000 light sources very easy and efficient but as far as I know there's no good technique to make shadows efficient as well Radiance Cascades despite the name is really about efficiently storing arbitrary spherical functions that vary spatially It would work just as well for shadow maps tl dr store a shadow map spatial tree where the nodes closer to the root have high angular resolution and nodes closer to leaves have low angular resolution where each shadow map sample reconstructs from the full resolution chain at a given position and direction Out of the box Radiance Cascades doesn't give you spatial sparsity as it was originally intended for global illumination So you could try a BVH like object partition over your lights rather than the fixed grid spatial partition from the original algorithm This might be necessary to get the quality you want Note as well you can effectively reproject shadow maps a little by doing shadow map space raytraces rather than single samples IIRC an old trick

107421166 Size is usually calculating end begin but it's up to the implementation I don't know if any implementation actually uses an int The syntax to use iterators is horrible I will not use it for loops if you use C inspector a range based for loop is just using iterators in that clean way And personally iterators are very clean if you just use auto template for the type And the rare situations where I need the index is usually if space is a problem using a uint16 t for index or I want to print an error showing the index Iterator checks also help a lot since vectors only invalidate if you actually go past the capacity so address sanitizer will not help while your code is potentially problematic But if you used msvc with the default debug flags or glib or is it libstdc D GLIBCXX DEBUG or libc LIBCPP HARDENING MODE DEBUG it will actually tell you when you use an invalid iterator even when the memory is perfectly valid even with custom asan poisoning Of course if you used a index there is no invalidation for a vector if you use it like a stack since that's only a problem for pointers iterators There is also no const ness and I think const iterators are actually very clutch when you are dealing with really annoying code but const should be avoided when in doubt using const correctly is really hard I really hate const everything mentality and of course pointers iterators are bigger than an int much bigger with checking enabled Also my favorite is std remove if and you can use it as a for loop substitute IF you are removing elements in the array while looping through it normally you just set the element to a value flag to be deleted BUT it has no early exit if you want to return an error so you need a exception or write your own remove if see cppreference or just set a fail flag and finish the loop And you could switch the container to almost anything

107388133 Writing technical docs for work and personal projects It's mostly convenience of source blocks org links to the specific part of the code For example lets say you want to trace the steps of a giant AWS serverless microservice hellscape for some big data project that uses all buzzwords imaginable or a legacy monolitic java piece of shit platform that has one foot on cloud services and another on in house XML statemachines You're being onboarded onto one of those projects and you have 2 moths of grace period where they leave you be while you're learning the hellscape they've put you in In those cases you might want to write down what's happeing and what's triggering what or which job schedules the next one which json configuration file sets off a workflow that deploys infraestructure or pipeline or whatever But text is not enough the actual code is important but you can't just put the entire source code for every relevant file so the next best thing are source blocks with the relevant pieces of code but the problem remains you lose the overal scope of the code so you include links to those files but they might change locations or the contents might change and so on and so on So I settled for a bit on org transclusion to fetch code and retain a connection to it's source and then realized I could make it point to a semi permanent location by pointing to specific git hashes or commits revs but there was no org link type for contents inside of git revs which brought me to make orgit file and now I'm working on org transclusion git to use that shit and make my life easier by writing better more reliable documentation for these babylonian projects I get put into from time to time

107404326 No The analysis is fine of a purely statistical foundation but nobody cares about the top half of that table lifetime size known is just a variable The language handles that for you when you write int i 0 Nobody needs to think about this It's the unknowns that take most of your memory and are most prone to causing issues Of those unknowns size known is often misleading You very very rarely actually know exactly how much space you will need if you know the size of one element there usually is an unknown number of elements Lifetime known is also misleading If the lifetime is short such as one scope then it's easy peasy to handle and you don't even think about it If the upper bound lifetime is measured in real time or as one scene or as part of a complex function then reserving all that memory until you're ABSOLUTELY sure it can't possibly be needed anymore may be too costly Imagine a program that recursively reads files keeping each file in memory until the entire process finishes just to avoid having to manage lifetimes Overall it sounds like a mathematical approach to memory management that has no bearing on real world applications Maybe it works for graphics I don't have much experience in graphics programming but it's surely not an optimal strategy for most programming

107404664 Keeping a pool of frequently allocated objects is a great thing to do but not really for reasons of memory safety It deduplicates memory skips unneeded disk reads and lets you centrally manage resources Especially in a videogame engine it's a good standard but I completely fail to see how it improves memory safety You still need to refcount it or otherwise manage its lifetime to avoid leaking and this brings back all the flaws of smart pointers It's just more centralized which makes it easier to debug in some ways and harder in others

107404326 With the linear allocator that releases all memory at once I always run into issues Overlapping lifetimes Imagine you want to read a png file decode the bytes then free the original raw png bytes but keep the decoded bytes Then you can't free the raw png bytes You have two options here Either just don't free but that's like saying I don't do memory management at all here Could be fine if you have enough memory but that just sidesteps the problem Or you have to pass in two allocators e g one for temporary allocation one for permanent ones you want to keep That's only a little annoying in this scenario and it's pretty clear what's temporary and what's permanent but I always run into situations where I suddenly have to route a second arena down a bunch of calls or create a new one ad hoc just to get some memory and it gets messy quickly Growing data structures Dynamic arrays are just so useful but if you only have a linear allocator you can only allocate at the top you can only dynamically grow something if it happens to be the very last thing you allocated which is never the case in non trivial situations In the general case you're just leaving the old memory behind With a growth factor of 2 you'd end up needing twice as much memory for your array because of that fragmentation That's fine again if you have enough memory but my point is that arena's just suck for this kind of allocation pattern Regular allocators handle it fine And if you're starting to think about adding a list of free blocks to your linear arena that can hold the blocks that some other data structure grew out of then you're essentially writing a bad general purpose allocator ad hoc in your arena Might as well use a generic malloc then Sometimes there's clear scenarios where you're just allocating a bunch of stuff linearly and then linear allocators are obviously great But trying to force them into all other cases seems like a bad idea

107404326 You are basically talking about arena and they still don't protect you from out of bound access As soon as you deal with pointers you take the risk of accessing invalid memory regions You could avoid it by always having a check that the address is valid but this is inneficient Anyway the issue has never been allocation itself but memory access patterns

41591397 I see what you re aiming at with the acoustic camera aperture synthesis and it makes sense in the right regime Short wavelengths dense apertures a real pressure field you can phase match and reconstruct etc But I m not tracking with the application to this specific case A 52 Hz line in water has a wavelength on the order of tens of meters so the limiting factors at that band are aperture size element geometry and propagation not a lack of exotic post processing Oversampling a 96 kHz front end and then subtracting cascaded moving averages just gives you a high pass residual and doesn t help with a low frequency CW line near the noise floor Most importantly what I was looking at at AUTEC behaved like an unmodulated 52 Hz EM pickup on the analog path not a propagating acoustic source flat carrier no Doppler no harmonics no inter element timing to exploit Your pipeline is interesting for true acoustic fields but I don t see a clean way to apply it to a non acoustic interference line Admittedly I haven't watched the videos yet but I will later

41590757 earths gravity creates a constant air pressure gradient pressure is higher at sea level and thus has a stronger refraction index It depends on heat you can see this yourself because of greater distortion on a hot day Also depends on humidity both change the density of air Like changing the density of the lens in glasses by changing the thickness of the glasses this causes the space time to bend down never up Again depends on where the hot air spots are Also light bends from refraction because of lensing like in a pair of glasses not because of spacetime distortion Although Earth's gravity also has a negligible effect on light the higher up you look the less the ray is affected by bending Generally true because you're looking through less atmosphere the ray going over the horizon will never touch the earth It doesn't have to Generally its arc will be greater than the curve of the Earth so it will escape the atmosphere rather than bounce back to Earth The atmospheric refraction for dry air at sea level is only about 1 0002941 The only reason two observers can see each other over the horizon is because they're above the level of the horizon and so the bending light can reach them even with a slight curve And so because the curve is so slight there's no level where it perfectly curves around the Earth as the ray goes further up and there's certainly not that perfect refraction across the whole globe

41590867 It depends on heat humidity this would play more of a role in creating noise in the atmosphere it is in no way like the gravitys inherent density gradient not because of spacetime distortion light doesnt bend in a vacum in only bends in gravities density gradient of matter the gradient is always the reason for relative space time distortion Generally true because you're looking through less atmosphere this is because refraction reflection of a material surface is dependent on angle of incidence two observers can see each other over the horizon not true because the gravity and the different air pressure layers are following the proposed curvature when the ray passed over curvature it is now relative to gravity angled up more than it was initially thus less bending

41590956 light doesnt bend in a vacum in only bends in gravities density gradient of matter the gradient is always the reason for relative space time distortion When light passes through a lens it doesn't work because of gravity it works because of different densities Light bends when this happens It's true that it doesn't happen in a vacuum light requires a medium for refraction to work Vacuums also aren't immune from gravity so I'm not sure how that works with your explanation Refraction also doesn't require a gradient consider a glass of water there's no gradient between the cup the water and air just an immediate change but you can still see the light is bent However it CAN happen in a gradient even though it's not REQUIRED Your explanation seems targeted at atmospheric refraction but it doesn't take into account glasses telescopes and other types of lenses not true because the gravity and the different air pressure layers are following the proposed curvature when the ray passed over curvature it is now relative to gravity angled up more than it was initially thus less bending Even if atmospheric refraction roughly acted like this it would again require a specific level or threshold of refraction and would not be inherently true of the globe model

red heads and black heads are jews everyone knew this years ago thats why ginger s are stereotyped as souless In medieval Europe being a redhead was no fun For centuries Europeans associated red hair with Jews For them the unusual hair color was a physical manifestation of Jewish otherness reflecting the belief that they were dangerous outsiders working with the Devil to sabotage Christian society from within During the Spanish Inquisition redheads were considered Jews and Renaissance masterworks such as Anthony van Dyck s The Taking of Christ portray Judas Iscariot the apostle who betrayed Jesus as a redhead The apostle s betrayal and his flaming locks then became bywords for supposed Jewish dishonesty and treachery In Shakespeare s As You Like It the heroine Rosalind refers to her lover s red hair as the dissembling color and suggests he s untrustworthy because of his resemblance to Judas Contemporary sources suggest that in the first productions of The Merchant of Venice a Shakespeare play that both embraces and questions anti Semitic tropes the Jewish merchant Shylock wore a red wig Now who else has red hair

subject: div Divination General
comment: Welcome to Divination General Come here for readings and a discussion of theory practice Every method is welcome Tarot Runes Cartomancy Scrying Pendulum Cleromancy I Ching Digital Oracles Tasseomancy Necromancy etc If you're NEW please READ the STICKY Recommended div links and books MEGA with Divination Books 2lEm1GL0qPIpSrQgrvA Guides made by some of our readers div starter spreads Thoth's tarot and rune guide 1ciFuMOVDIkA18d9Rw Zkklgigx Y4XzJkG VeMTYWcic Hijinks' revised divination guide A compiled Rider Waite card explanation Useful tips before posting If you're a reader post that you're offering readings and what information is required from the querent the same goes for trading Look for posts to determine if there's an active reader what's needed and before posting check if they finished reading already Some readers will refuse to do certain readings respect that choice Do not harass readers if your query is refused skipped We do our best to maintain chill and good vibes Traders should respect that a traded read will be granted as per an agreement of trade Free readers have the option of picking their queries Bullshit queries get bullshit answers Vague queries get vague answers Making an AQ air query by not addressing a reader in particular is possible but doesn't guarantee an answer Avoid making the same query repeatedly and or to different readers in a short period of time as this may lead to more confusion Provide feedback when applicable and be considerate to the reader We're a growing community many readers are starting and need to know what they are doing right or wrong Let's help each other to improve Previous thread 41594625

subject: Have you found meaning in your suffering
comment: Have you replayed the memories of the lost loves the addictions the dead friends and family the sickness and illness the sadness and despair the hard times knowing you wouldn't be the person you are today without them and been able to smile Have you stared the pattern in the face and were filled with joy knowing that you can make it different this time Have you been able to change what you can and leave behind what you cannot with grace Have you realized the broken dreams from your childhood had to be delayed so you could suffer first Have you realized the vices you've picked up over the years were meant to make you stronger not hold you back Have you been able to walk through the door that opened after the last one shut instead of staying in the room Have you realized you will be hurt again and that time you'll be able to appreciate it Have you realized that everything happened the way it did so you could be here and now to make the best of it Have you laughed knowing the answers have been in front of you this entire time and you couldn't see it until now Have you approached the void to scream and this time it was with love instead of despair then it roared back with love to you Have you seen the sun peak through your window in the morning and realized you get to see the light every day not just when you die Have you realized that no one has suffered quite like you have and that's a beautiful thing anon

41600580 41600593 I'm sometimes in a similar state due to living a long time with chronic illness What has made a difference for me is Reading good fiction that inspires you or moves you emotionally biographies can work too Eating well Mild exercise such as walking Exploring different religions and spiritualities join a local group if you can find one that isn't toxic and cult y Avoid hellfire religions ie much of Christianity especially low church protestant sometimes Catholics and even Orthodox churches if they've been infested with orthobro converts and avoid dissociative religions like Buddhism and Gnosticism Actually it's hard to say with Buddhism It's a real mixed bag since it can teach you some useful ways of thinking and meditating but can also make dissociation and depression worse depending on the person Some Buddhists can be really toxic too Myself I'm a Christian Universalist meaning I believe hell more like purgatory is temporary and everybody is saved in the end This has been incredibly uplifting for me I attend an Anglican Episcopalian if you're in the US church every Sunday and they're generally very chill though it depends what region you live in and can vary from church to church Catholics and Orthodox on the internet give this impression of being super stern and strict and pious but in real life at an actual church they're often just nice kind ordinary people If you want some suggestions for stuff to watch listen to along those lines love not vengeance I recommend the podcast Grace Saves All and the youtube channels Love Unrelenting and Jason Clark Rethinking God With Tacos Maybe check out John Crowder's The Consuming Fire series also Wish you the best

24922747 2 2 Whether this deficit was an issue of mental health or of apathy it matters little except to illustrate his general distaste for his official research work and how much time he invested focusing on unrelated studies while doing the bare minimum to push his grant work along intentionally avoiding attention one way or another He had no awards no honors and the bare minimum number of publications that was considered necessary to survive through graduate work On Ivan s desk lay his current manuscript entitled CHARACTERIZATION OF VILOCIN S CHELATING IONIC NANOSTRUCTURE An abysmal state of affairs it represented more an anthology of various drafts mixed and matched without any apparent intent with printed datasheets scattered with datapoints alone no labels no dates and no further information to sort by Notwithstanding this Ivan could clearly identify the most recent and luckily most significant experiments from these and was working to convert them into a publishable format He would put on his noise cancelling headphones turn on a video while leaning back and rhythmically tap his feet and fingers while intermittently entering values The work was described less as a veritable flow and more like the creeping of molten metal through a narrow conduit before folding over itself and slowing to a dead stop Whereas the professors and peers in the department would be appalled at such a sight it was of little concern to Ivan He had produced his previous manuscripts with a similar degree of disorder and managed to escape unscathed He had no doubt in his ability to salvage the current disaster into a success although one which would pass publication before being read and referenced very little going forward He would produce it on time if not slightly and always acceptably behind schedule

comment: Do you want to be a writer Send off to magazines and kickstart your writing career Start with short stories and branch out to a novel once you feel you have what it takes as a writer LITERARY FICTION HEAT Magazine t contact Pays much more than genre magazines Overland Pays well for fiction and essays 550 poems 170 Ploughshares Ploughshares pays 45 per printed page with a minimum payment of 90 and a maximum of 450 per author for general submissions New Yorker tact estimates suggest it pays around 7 500 for a short story POETRY 32 Poems elines 25 per poem Oxford Poetry html Poetry Magazine it SCIENCE FICTION Clarkesworld bmissions 1000 22000 words no exceptions 12c USD per word No horror but dark SF F permitted Asimov's writers guidelines Up to 7500 words at 10c per word USD Fantasy Science Fiction tm Up to 25 000 words in length 8 12 c USD per word You must read a sample of the magazine before sending Interzone Digital ns Maximum of 5000 words 1 5c EURO per word Double spaced and emailed FANTASY Beneath Ceaseless Skies com submissions Up to 15 000 words 8c per word USD Provides feedback on rejections HORROR The Dark Magazine mission guidelines We pay 5 cents word for original fiction up to 6 000 words Deadlands s guidelines The Deadlands seeks stories about death they pay pro rates at 10 word for original fiction Nightmare Magazine ubmission guidelines Dark fiction from psychological horror to traditional supernatural tales A top tier pro rate market Pay 0 08 USD per word for original fiction Apex Magazine issions Payment for original fiction is 08 per word up to 7 500 words Minimum of 50

24922815 Are clich s dulling your intro's hook Avoid that AND get your reader up to speed with some crafty past tense and exposition It will cover all the ground you need and you don't need to start in bed Here's an example Chapter 1 Another day just like any other thought John to himself after taking a sip for his fifth coffee of the day having woken up at precisely 06 00 after working late the night before at the office in order to secure a lucrative new client for his real estate company's budding expansion into deepest darkest Transylvania before the final team meeting this afternoon For two weeks his wife had to put up with late nights and by now she was curiously pale which John put down to a lack of sleep or perhaps an iron deficiency And just what were those marks on her neck Or is it he mused as he recalled the office's new apprentice and how he couldn't quite put his finger on why he found him mildly offputting And that trainee's name Drake Ula from Romania As you can see my story drops you right into the action whilst also giving you all the information you need to understand what's at steak And the way I framed it as John's thoughts makes it nearly impossible for the discerning reader to realise I am doing it I love writing

24870923 The Witches Seven sat about Which hectic heptad rattled out Upon all rhymed and metred verse We call our half too clever Curse A numpty numbered cadence cage The remnant of a rancid age When flights of frenzied overeach Bore writing different to speech How blessed we'll be to hear at last The final knell of jingles past Quick Sisters Sisters Gather round By rhymes unstressed by stress unbound In Frelin Grove we congregate To thin Man's verse of what we hate Oh horrid horrid hateful thing Be careful Sister not to sing You err more rhythmic than you should And that can lead to nothing good A good thing we're not held to this Indeed It would be odious Suppose our cauldron brewed some borst Then we'd be forced and we'd be forced To rhyme the word that followed it Thus neutered is a Witch s wit But worry not my Sisters weird Their jingle jank need not be feared Men suffer so But here we're flocked A remedy we'll here concoct Let's add a sharktooth in the mix A mason's stones No less than six Into these bubbles must we hurl The labia of a virgin girl Deaf mother's ears Mute aunty's tongue Giraffe's vocal chords by blowfly stung Okay then Sisters settle down We have our broth of earthy brown The time is nigh that we rejoice But first we must unite our voice If we're to vanquish Rhyme tonight Prepare yourselves The Spell recite HUBBLE BUBBLE TOIL'S TROUBLE BE MORE SUBTLE BUBBLE DOUBLE That's it Sister's Hold on shoot I forgot the rhymer's foot Within the cauldron must it plop Right Sorry Sisters From the top HUBBLE BUBBLE TOIL'S TROUBLE BE MORE SUBTLE BUBBLE DOUBLE 'T is so The mist of magic flies Sisters we must avert our eyes And in a flash it shall disperse Against the evils of Man's verse Look There it goes Wait Don't look No Okay We've still got one more go HUBBLE BUBBLE TOIL'S TROUBLE BE MORE SUBTLE BUBBLE DOUBLE Right Here we are And ever hence Shall sound make way for common sense A better practice we shall craft The language pure the effort halved Of form of Rhyme of merit free And we shall call it Poetry 'T is just as well no poet knows That there is such a thing as prose

24868365 And a few extra thread questions from previous threads just to be safe What kinds of magic psychic abilities and or other powers exist in your world And if multiple types exist how do they interact with each other if at all If the different types can be combined what is the result And if not what is the reason How do people use gain access to the magic And what are the most important things to consider remember when creating a magic system s or power system and what mistakes to avoid How did you make your own Is there anything that the magic or powers explicitly cannot do and if yes what And how much of the limits of the abilities are inherent versus a lack of understanding On the subject of hyper advanced technology what exists in your world and what do you need to remember when creating including it What about magitech or other tech that incorporates powers what can you say on that Do the people in your setting believe in any celestial beings like Angels or something similar And do these beings actually exist and if so how accurate are the beliefs How about Demons or similar beings how accurate are their beliefs to reality And how do you add your own twist to them or to Angels Are there any other categories of otherworldly entities in your world like the Fae Yokai Ghosts and specters Grim Reapers Elementals etc If so how are they related to Angels Demons or each other if at all and what are they like What about the gods in your world what are they like how are their pantheons structured And what is their relationship with the other mystical entities in the setting do they have any specific groups of Angels serving specific gods etc

24868365 Perfect I asked for help last thread but didn't get much hopefully things go better this time To sum it up my races are all aligned with two or three of the six elements Light Fire Wind Water Earth and Void with humans being the Light and Void race with the elements informing traits of the race like their preferred environment For example the Fire and Water race is the Naga so their nation is on a set of tropical volcanic islands and they re equally comfortable in the water and on the beach and the Fire Earth race is Dwarves etc To be clear the idea was that the elemental alignments were the result of the gods of the respective elements being the primary contributors in the design of the race in question So for dwarves while they still have traces of the other elements in them such as having liquids in their bodies instead of just being molten rock in a stone shell because they have Water in them etc the mentioned elements like Fire and Earth for dwarves dominate the others In addition in some cases one element is dominant over the other s like Dwarves being a bit more aligned with Earth than Fire though there are occasional exceptions like Dwarves that tend more towards Fire Things like a Dwarf with a Void affinity would be extremely rare and usually the case of inter species pairings since the races were designed using the same basic template they can interbreed but the child is always or at least 99 of the time the race of the mother That make sense Humans would be the Light Void race before I forget I just need some help with filling in some of the combinations especially the three element ones and I can use some suggestions please

24883616 I have completely forgotten both the title and the author It was a long time ago I don't even remember thinking that the book was anything special just that the topic was unusual There weren't a lot of stone age books around in the first place but I read everything I could find Clan of the Cave Bear has slight supernatural elements but not really enough to qualify as fantasy Basically imagine just your standard stone age life in a small hunter gatherer tribe but the main character is a boy who died a hunting accident if I remember correctly and the other characters consider him a protective spirit and sacrifice food to him the flavor of which he is able to enjoy through the smoke There was this other tribe too with whom the main character's tribe exchanged daughters to avoid inbreeding but they didn't really like each other and the tribes ended up fighting each other in the end There were no overt fantasy elements visible to a skeptic time traveler I really think branching out of the standard fantasy box is helpful when doing worldbuilding Fantasy is not supposed to be limited to a small subset of its possibilities

24905279 That sounds like The Magic Goes Away by Larry Niven In that story the use of magic consumed the local mana eventually resulting in zones where magic didn't work at all If the mana had instead been gaseous and mobile this would have resulted in evenly lowering mana concentrations all over the world You could also have the mana be a resource that is continually produced by something such as sacred trees or volcanic eruptions or mysterious ancient technology that no one understands any more Any reductions at the source for whatever reason would then lead to lower levels of ambient mana The Coldfire Trilogy by C S Friedman had the fae sentient mana surge with earthquakes that happen often because the planet is tectonically young In The Night Land by William Hope Hodgson the Earth Current is life force mana electricity that comes from deep underground in certain places and is also an exhaustible resource like oil

24922646 Entirely No not me On the one hand I sometimes care about a culture associated with a certain language or care about the intersection language other culture like I care about the music which German poems are set to in Lieder and I care about the fact there are apparently better books written for classical languages in German and French than in English and I care about the fact there are many books written in German etc On the other hand I tend to view language as separate from any culture and view language as pure ideas much like mathematics and music You can describe the way a bridge is constructed with geometrical expressions but that doesn't mean that those geometrical expressions are intrinsically part of that bridge In the same way German grammar for example is not intrinsically part of anything cultural Grammar as well as logic and rhetoric as a tool for thought is my main interest when it comes to language overall this is also not intrinsically connected to communication language even without any communication at all is how we structure thoughts

24916474 Austrian economics is invalid from its first premise because it begins with the individual as the primary and ultimate form of analysis In every science the discernment of laws is only possible on a macro level This is especially so in economics where the chaotic and unpredictable actions of individuals create emergent laws which the individuals unknowingly participate in though they themselves but dimly perceive it hence the necessity for the study of economics Austrian school of economics starts at the individual but it doesn't have to end at the individual Many Austrian school economists use macroeconomic data to validate their theories which perhaps stem from a priori reasoning centered around the individual and I don't know why that is so controversial when game theory does exactly the same and it isn't questioned and praxeology could be understood as a precursor of game theory Moreover using data mindlessly to infer correlations can lead you to for example reject the supply demand law because in X circumstances the prices of some product went up with an increasing supply ignoring how the demand which is not easy to measure could have increased at higher rates There are many hidden variables and hidden interactions between variables in the economy which makes virtually impossible to obtain empiric economic laws Unlike with systems in lower order sciences by lower order I mean closer to physics the economy can hardly be confined in an experiment with a controlled atmosphere so that the only variables involved are those whose correlations are desired to be studied That excessively empiricist tendency leads to wanting to statally control the economy because for every positive science there has to be an engineering we have laws to do so right Well that's wrong even from a utilitarian perspective because there are second third and Nth order consequences to intervention which haven't been studied in the empirical models and those consequences don't necessarily have to be lower as the order increases they can wind up to the point of recession And finally the perspective doesn't have to be merely utilitarian because intervention handles the resources of other people and we shouldn't be allowed to do everything in the name of economics just like doctors are not allowed to do medical research with their patients without consent

Some years ago I replicated his journey with a few extra pitstops along the way I did it over multiple visits since I stayed longer in places like Venice but it was a tremendous experience I presume you're reading the auden translation that's the one I went with The trouble with Goethe is that he's very enthusiastic about the classical and ends up missing or dismissing so much of Italy There's a very good companion book of all the sketches and art he had commissioned while on his trip Though I think it's German only If at a later time you decide to read Montaigne's Italian journal you will find out he visited many of the same places but was interested in completely different things Goethe almost to his detriment was a very learned man He'd read Winckelmann he knew the places you had to see the paintings you have to find the churches you had to visit To Montaigne none of that mattered he was much more interested in the prostitutes and the liveliness of the place Goethe also wrote some very good poems while in Rome and I recommend looking them up in translation

24921104 It's written well enough for a game but it's a good example of why video games as a medium are weak for story telling It does a lot of shit that wouldn't fly in another medium It's presented as a detective mystery to start and there's a case that being a detective mystery isn't the point but it completely fails as one in any case The actual mystery aspect is garbage compared to just primary school library filler you can't realistically solve it until the game answers it for you at all because it plainly isn't structured for you to do so It's paced that you don't actually receive any usable information until the closing act When it comes to the rest the plot they don't interact with the game well The mechanical aspect of the game is that you roll dice to determine success or failures and to the games credit you get some value out of failing since scenes play out differently but it means the narrative and characterization bounces all over the place to accommodate the gameplay aspects It's very fatty which is necessary to give you play time It makes an effort to have themes going on to its credit but again you have to spend such a large amount of the game playing which means most of the playtime doesn't feed into them at all People debate a lot over what the game is trying to say because whatever the right answer is the message is garbled up since everyone going through it has a different play experience Like it doesn't have to compete with high literature I've read some serious bargain bit slop that I thought was better even though Disco Elysium is better written than most games

24880560 It's honestly the weakest it has ever been in the series in my opinion The lore is uninteresting and too character focused with revenges assassinations secret plots brotherly rivalries etc which would be much better explored in a book and you can really see that they come from a bookish mindset more specifically from Martin's mindset I do not believe that you can do effective character focused narration in a videogame where so much is supposed to be left to the player's imagination DS1 was able to manage everything with much more elegance because it was playing on a smaller scale On the scale of DS1 environmental narration could be executed perfectly a smaller character cast fewer events and easier to trigger made it so that characters like Solaire or Sigmeyer could be narrated to the fullest In Elden Ring you'll often begin a quest and meet a character again after 10 hours of gameplay having completely forgotten who the fucker was or what he or she wanted This further complicated by the fact that the characters often have complex personal motives that you can't unpack without being updated on the lore In DS1 Solaire is a guy who wants to help me beat bosses and find his own meaning in life Siegmeyer just wants to go through the same parts of the map as I do but he's always stuck until I open doors etc these are relatable goals easy to understand and remember that also tell something to the player about what kind of player you can be And you don't need to know much about the history of the world to want to help these guys In ER I think they did a better work with the DLC than the base game The quests are mostly set out in the beginning and are easier to follow there is a central understandable plot about Miquella and environmental narration makes more sense with bits like the Shaman Village Shadowkeep Rauh etc There are lots of ideas Some things are still bloated one finger ruin would have been sufficient and for as much as I love Igon his quest and Bayle do not tie into anything relevant for SOTE but overall they did a much better job in guiding the player through the story than they did in the base game Generally speaking I think narration in DS1 is still their best and its genius in its own way it's engaging it can feel very close to you personally and make you reflect about life and it's untranslatable outside of the videogame media Elden Ring is a great game and very fun but it's not as deep from a lore point of view and in terms writing it often feels bloated

24913063 These are Nabokov's opinions not OP's If you read Nabokov's lecture on Joyce apparently he was disturbed by the lack of punctuation and he autistically wrote all the missing commas by pencil in his copy of the book I think he wanted to somehow point out that the book wasn't perfect because he tried very hard to play Joyce's game and despite not liking FW he quotes it extensively everywhere the whole color games in Lolita are likely inspired by FW rainbow children if you check the annotated edition But despite all the snobbery Nabokov also wrote this Let people compare me to Joyce by all means but my English is patball to Joyce's champion game A genius He recognized that he wasn't as good which takes some courage considered people hailed his own works as masterpieces and he was clearly aiming at being a kind of modernist master in fact one could argue he was the last of that generation of writers in a sense Pic related is generally a great book if you want a writer's insight on how to read classics He goes on autistically about stuff like being able to reconstruct a map of places in Madame Bovary with drawings attachad based on prose alone to drive a point about how one can write in a precise manner And he gives at least in my opinion very good advice on how to navigate each single episode of Ulysses plus discovering some internal references by himself I think he was the first or one of the first to point the finger on the man with the brown macintosh possibly being Joyce himself or something
